newsitem.title: UK: LME tumbles by close, unnerves others.
newsitem.headline: LME tumbles by close, unnerves others.

text.p: A swift downturn in zinc after a relatively calm morning helped take other base metals from their highs by the close of Wednesday's London Metal Exchange (LME) business.
Recent star zinc dropped to a low of $1,440 a tonne as large sell-orders between the afternoon rings emerged.

One trader said that an offer around the market near $1,490 was well received by floor trading members but this confidence was quickly sidelined as even lower offers were seen in second ring LME trading.
"It came at of the blue, noone had expected the market to be offered so low in such a short period of time," one zinc trader said.
This was enough to send the other base metals lower.
"Where the sell orders came from is unsure and is likely to remain unexplained until the dust settles," the trader added.
Several others suggested it was liquidation by investment funds and nervous longs who believed that Chinese smelters that had been running short positions were now square.

But with nearby dates still remaining tight others said that the Chinese smelters could not be square. "The backwardation remains strong...if the Chinese are now level then we should see a contango," a trader said.
Final three months business was at $1,460, down on Tuesday's $1,480 close and an earlier high of $1,530. On Monday prices peaked at a seven-year high of $1,675.
The cash to three months spread was indicated at around $95, against $70 on Tuesday.
Copper at one stage dived to a low of $2,285 after zinc's decline. But by the close of business once the "panic selling" had subsided three months delivery bounced back to $2,305, down from $2,359.
Traders said LME stock increases was helping to dent copper and expected further downside pressure on Thursday.
"Despite the late bounce copper remains under pressure after visiting levels below $2,300," a trader said.
Aluminium was moved below expected support at $1,700 after an earlier period of stability. It earlier peaked at a 19-month high of $1,717.
Traders said aluminium's decline was a knee-jerk reaction to zinc and copper. It was last at $1,697, down $3. Nickel after racing to a high of $7,580 dived to end at $7,360, compared with $7,495.
Tin was last at $5,550, down $25 from its high but up on Tuesday's $5,410 close. Traders said tin earlier found support from buy-stops as it corrected from a recent oversold condition.
Lead was quiet and settled $3 lower at $632, while alloy was quoted at $1,510/20, down $5.
